displayed_text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So this is quite a paradoxical approach. Patient: Okay, good. Doctor: And it turns out that you’re absolutely right. We’ve known for a long time for about seventy years that testosterone can feed into your prostate cancer. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: However, we have recently discovered in the last three or four years that they can take a patient who has had low testosterone levels for a very long time they call that hormone-resistant prostate cancer or castration-resistant prostate cancer is another term Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um many patients don’t like that term. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um so that’s just hormone resistant. Patient: Okay. Doctor: In that context only, if you give back super-high doses of testosterone to the patient, and the way that we do that is we give an intra-muscular injection. It’s an injection of testosterone into the muscle that is either thigh muscle or the butt muscle. Patient: Uh huh.

Family Member 1: I’ll call. Doctor: Yeah. All right. Family Member 1: So did W___ then tell you that he's been getting these cramps in his legs? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: Okay, that and then number two, he did say you know, his gums are real sensitive, but he never told me. Patient: Oh no, no, no. That was when I was taking the Elida. Doctor: Yep. Patient: Or when I would I brush my teeth. Doctor: Yep. Yep. So is it better now on the medicine? Patient: It’s gone. Family Member 1: So that might happen with this pill now, right? Or we don't know? Doctor: We don't know, anything is possible, but most of it is, you know, it's going to be very cyclical, right? Patient: Right.

Family Member: I’m like, wow. Patient: My, gosh. We was in Langa, and then Langa- Doctor: So did, was that part of the tour to see that or that was just you could not see that in just where you were going? Patient: Everything was part of the tour. Yeah. Family Member: Um hum. It’s all included. Patient: Everything is, and then you have some passages- Doctor: I mean, like the poor areas of the country, that was part of the tour, or you just look out the window and that’s what you see? Patient: When, when we went to Langa, that was, that was different than where they was going. So we, we, they had a package to go to Langa. We went to- Doctor: What’s Langa? Patient: Langa is a little town. Family Member: It’s a little town outside of Cape Town. Patient: Right.

Patient: She knows V____. Doctor: Right. Patient: Then she left me. Doctor: She left you. Patient: Remember I told you last summer. Doctor: Yeah you did. I remember there was some family issues. Patient: Yeah and she’s gone man. Doctor: She’s gone because of this yeah. Patient: Yeah and so I said I meet, you know I met people, they really like me for me and maybe want to get to another step. Doctor: Step and they don’t feel comfortable. Patient: You know. Doctor: Do they know about your situation? Have you talked about that?

Patient: It paralyzes or something. I don’t like that feeling. Doctor: Yeah. No, I don’t want to wait until you get paralyzed either. Patient: It would be in my arms. Doctor: Right. Patient: It would be in my arms and my feet, my toes. Doctor: Yeah, because, but we don’t want to wait until you know it totally messes up with your… Doctor: …walking and stuff. Patient: It’s coming a long… Doctor: Yeah, yeah, but the cancer has stayed in check for a really long time with the chemo… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …so I think uh so far the chemo has done you good. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Alright. So today we’ll go ahead and I know you gave G____ the list of medications…

Patient: And, and I want you to know that I, I thought this discussion was going to be today. Doctor: I’m glad I met your expectations. Patient: Yeah. I thought this was going to come up, and I said, okay. But it is what it is. Healthcare Professional: I will communicate with L___, and she’ll contact you probably tomorrow, about she will get in contact with K. She will set everything up for you. Patient: Okay. Thank you. Doctor, it’s always good to see you. And thank you for your advice. And we’re going to follow your lead. Doctor: And I’ll follow your lead. We’ll help each other. Patient: Yes sir. Yes sir. Now, do I need to go to K___ to get a prescription? Doctor: You’ll wait to hear from us. L___ will help us to do that. L___ will help us to get the prescription. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Because normally I think the last two times we were able to, I just told them I would pay for them out of pocket here, but that’s okay. Doctor: I wouldn’t recommend that. Patient: Oh kay. Healthcare Professional: I’m going to give you my card with my number, in case you don’t hear from L___ tomorrow. MD Exits

Patient: No. Doctor: You get them? Patient: Typically not. Actually, I never have. Doctor: You want one? Patient: Um, going into this, hearing from other patients, they say it’s advisable. I’ve heard, I don’t know. I, uh Doctor: I’m a big fan. Patient: Then, I guess I will. Patient: Yes! I’ll take one. Doctor: You’ve got cancer, and I’m gonna treat ya. I’d like ya not to get the flu in the midst of therapy. Patient: Okay, then. Doctor: Because, then, it’s one thing I can cross off the list. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Umm. We could do it today, or we could do it in a couple weeks when you’re gonna switch the

Patient: You know? J___ will probably ask more. (Laughs) Doctor: As I expect her to. (Laughs) Patient: She’s my little warrior. Doctor: Huh. I know. Patient: You know? It was you know I, I can of expected it. I was worried about hearing that but you’ve got to do what you’ve got to do. Doctor: You’ve got to do what you’ve got to do. And you know we could always switch course elsewhere. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I mean this is. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I have to say, though, that you look better today post radiation than before we started. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You were really uncomfortable. You know? Patient: Yeah. And now I did have some.

Family Member: Out of the three which one would you recommend. Doctor: Well, let me tell you a little bit more about what what the clinical trials entail, because then I'll tell you what I think, based on our conversation last time to what we should look into first. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So the two clinical trials one is called the MAP study. And I might have briefly mentioned this last time, this is a study of muscadine grapeseed extract. Family Member: Yes you did. Doctor: Yeah. So this is a study- is a randomized study for people with a particular genotype. So what that means is what what we know is that when some people take antioxidants like you know, these a lot like pomegranate or the muscadine grapeseed extract- Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: - some people actually do have an improvement in their PSA, their PSA is go down and, but when we give it to everybody, we don't really see an effect. What we found is that there are probably people with a certain genotype, meaning that certain changes in their DNA, which are like totally normal, about a quarter of the population has this. Patient: Mm. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: Those people are more likely to respond, it seems. So with this trial is first we check your genotype. So that's step one. And then if you are the particular genotype, which, for the purposes of we'll just call it AA. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: That means that you're eligible for the study-

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Doctor: That’s nice but you got to come back. So when are you coming back? Doctor: Okay. I mean it’s fine if you want to stay there. PAT Yeah. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: It’s not like the medicine is gonna be delivered tomorrow. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: By the time I work out all this paperwork, it’s a while. Patient: Okay, alright. That’s cool. Doctor: So you duke it out with your wife – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - in terms of whether you go or not, that’s on you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You just know, I have to have you be careful. Patient: I know.

Family Member: In January. Doctor: So if you’ve already got an appointment for January – Family Member: January thirty. Doctor: Yeah, that will be your next shot. So typically I schedule that no matter what. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’re always going to come in and see me or (says name) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay. And the chemo is what we’re here to talk about today- Patient: Okay. Doctor: It is you know if you’re still interested in the clinical trial, have questions for me about the clinical trial, then I’m going to bring D___ in. So she’s the research nurse that I’ll sort of is it doable, can we get started, and what you have to do to go forward, okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then once you guys sign the paperwork and we move forward, then you and I will pick a date to pick the day the chemo starts. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Number two, can we do additional molecular testing that you and I talked about early on… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …which you know we use a company called Caris. Patient: Right. Doctor: uh Molecular Intelligence. There are many. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: But here once we send it they bill your insurance. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Then we get the report back and we’re up to about eight hundred genes that they look at. And some of that actually is important for us because it sometimes can direct what we do whether it’s a trial for now or later and also gets us a sense of what that cancer looks like blueprinted. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Which you know it’s a different blueprint than what you were born with. Patient: Yes.

Patient: What about the finasteride I'm still on? Doctor: That's okay. Because you've been taking that for your pee and you’re just being- Patient: I don’t know what’s the other one. Family Member: So okay. Patient: Finasteride and folic acid, we're the only other ones I was taking. Family Member: There's no reason why you can't you take calcium with vitamin nuts. Doctor: No, that's fine. Family Member: Is there anything that's totally good? No, no? As far as meds? Doctor: Well, I don't like Selenium and I don't like vitamin E for prostate cancer patients that's greater than the recommended. Family Member: Selenium? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I take a multivitamin.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? So we’ll check probably after about twelve weeks, huh, about how it’s going. Huh, but our job will be to cheer lead you through the first three to four cycles, huh, adjusting the dose if you’re having side effects and they’re too severe. But most people are able to get through it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so my recommendation is that we stop the abiraterone, continue the prednisone. If you’re interested in the clinical trial, I can at least start with, huh, printing it out for you, and letting you read it, and see how often you need to be here, let the nurse know that you’re potentially interested, and she can, huh, do insurance clearance. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if they say your insurance is not going to pay for it, the decision’s made. Patient: Right. Doctor: If the decision says the insurance will cover it, after you’ve read it, huh, you could say, yeah, I’m interested. And then we’ll bring you back to have a formal discussion about what that looks like. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so all that can happen in the next three to four weeks. Huh, so you come off the abiraterone. We’ll see if this gets better. Watch your potassium. But you do some reading. Huh, if there’s other people you want to talk about the trial, people that have been on it, huh, or have any concerns about, you know, being here so much, let us know, because we can work on some of that with you. Patient: Now, the only thing, huh, mainly. The vitamin C, if I get it, I might not use something, and if I don’t get it, it ain’t going to affect the chemo I’m getting to try to do-? Doctor: Right. Because that’s what everybody gets. That’s what everybody gets. Patient: Right.

Patient: Well then – Doctor: And then we think about what’s necessary. Patient: That’s what the, the doctor at P_ said. Doctor: I know! Patient: He say, he say – Doctor: I talked to that doctor, remember? Patient: Yeah! You told me he talked to you. Doctor: I know. Patient: You say. Doctor: So, I said, I know you. That if we did that and everything else, you would just sort of give up. You’d be like, “I’m done. I can just barely -- my quality of life is here.” But I have to tell you, if you really needed it. One, I think your quality of life would actually be much better because you’d be so symptomatic from that problem, you couldn’t ride your bike. You couldn’t go around the block. You couldn’t do anything! You’d just be soiling yourself constantly! So, if that came to be the issue, you would want it done just to improve your quality of life. Patient: Okay. Listen. Doctor: But I also know that that’s not something you would do proactively because the thought of having a bag scares the heck out of you. I know that. I got it. And now I just threw in two possible bags that’s even more frightening. So, I need you to focus on what we have to do next. We gotta get some systemic stuff swirling through your bloodstream –
